Fig. 1 Synthesis scheme, TEM micrographs and EDS elemental maps, and HRTEM micrographs of (a−c) CeTiOx, and (d−f) CeCuOx derived from bimetallic templates. The inset in Figs. 1c and 1f are the SEM images of the corresponding bimetallic catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) XRD patterns, and (b) micro-Raman spectra of CeTiOx, CeCuOx derived from bimetallic templates (Notes: The CeO2 derived from Ce-MOF was cited as a reference catalyst.). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) NOx conversion of CeTiOx, CeCuOx and CeO2 catalysts for LT-SCR, and (b) catalytic performance of CeTiOx catalyst for LT-SCR in 5 vol% H2O and 100 ppm SO2 at 225 °C. [Reaction conditions: 600 ppm NH3, 600 ppm NO, 3 vol% O2, and N2 for balance; The catalyst weight is 0.2 g, GHSV is 150,000 h−1]. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) XPS full spectra and narrow XPS spectra of (b) Ce 3d, (c) Ti 2p, (d) Cu 2p, and (e) O 1 s for CeTiOx, and CeCuOx catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Acidic characterization by Pyridine-IR spectra for (a) CeTiOx, (b) CeCuOx, and (c) CeO2 catalysts after pyridine adsorption at 50 °C, 150 °C and 250 °C. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 NH3-TPD profiles of CeTiOx, CeCuOx, and CeO2 catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 In situ DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption on (a) CeTiOx, (b) CeCuOx, (c) CeO2 as a function of reaction temperatures, (d) acid amount and (e) acid percentage content of CeTiOx, CeCuOx and CeO2 at 50 °C. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 In situ DRIFT spectra of NO+O2 adsorption on (a) CeTiOx, (b) CeCuOx, and (c) CeO2 as a function of reaction temperatures. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 In situ DRIFT spectra of reaction between NO + O2 and pre-adsorbed NH3 on (a) CeTiOx, (b) CeCuOx, and (c) CeO2 at 225 °C. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 In situ DRIFT spectra of reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO + O2 on (a) CeTiOx, (b) CeCuOx, and (c) CeO2 at 225 °C. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 (a) In situ DRIFT spectra of SO2 + O2 adsorption on CeTiOx; and DRIFT spectra of (b) NH3 adsorption, (c) NO + O2 adsorption on fresh and SO2-pretreated CeTiOx at 225 °C; differences in DRIFT spectra of CeTiOx with/without H2O for (d) NH3 adsorption, (e) NO + O2 adsorption, and (f) NH3 + NO + O2 adsorption at 225 °C. Low-temperature selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (LT-SCR) is a promising approach for NOx remediation. This work utilized bimetallic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) to prepare CeMOx (M=Ti, Cu) catalysts allowing the homogeneous distribution of promoters to investigate LT-SCR explicitly. The strong interfacial interaction between nanoscale-mixed components was characterized on CeTiOx by HRTEM, micro-Raman, and XPS, resulting in high acidity and good redox properties with abundant Ce3+ and Ti4+. It obtained over 80% conversion from 180 °C to 300 °C with 100% N2 selectivity, and maintained stable performance in SO2/H2O at a high GHSV of 150,000 h−1. In situ DRIFTS reveals that NH3 adsorption was promoted on CeTiOx, which accelerated reaction between NOx and adsorbed NH3 via Eley-Rideal mechanism. Meanwhile, the aliovalent substitution of ceria by Cu2+ was observed on CeCuOx, forming oxygen vacancies. Its high redox properties enhanced NOx conversion by Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism, but triggered NH3 peroxidation, leading to poor N2 selectivity. Graphical Abstract Bimetallic MOF-derived CeMOx with homogenous distribution of promoters and ceria was utilized to investigate on the role of redox/acidic promoter for low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction of NOx. ga1 Keywords Bimetallic oxides Low-temperature NH3-SCR of NOx Surface acidity Redox property SO2 resistance Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR) is one of the most powerful techniques that widely utilized in the denitration of flue gas and other stationary sources. The remediation of low-temperature flue gas typically requires a temperature lower than 300 °C, which commercial NH3-SCR catalysts (e.g., V2O5-WO3/TiO2) fail to meet this crucial requirement [1]. Several investigations in recent years have demonstrated that CeO2 with a unique reversible Ce3+/Ce4+ cycle is a potential candidate catalyst for low-temperature NH3-SCR (LT-SCR) [2,3]. However, CeO2 suffers from low N2 selectivity and insufficient activity [3,4]. Furthermore, it is vulnerable to deactivation in sulfur-containing stack gases, forming the sulfate species that covers the catalyst surfaces and blocks the active sites [5]. Doping CeO2 by promoters to form mixed transition metal oxide (i.e., CeMOx) has shown to be a promising method for developing an active LT-SCR catalyst. Modifications of CeO2 by titania showed high SO2 resistance, which afforded a better performance than CeO2/SiO2 and CeO2/Al2O3 [6,7]. However, a high temperature (i.e., 260 ℃) is required to achieve over 90% conversion on CeO2/TiO2, which is unfavorable for LT-SCR. Interestingly, a few studies reported a low catalytic reaction temperature (<200 °C) in CeO2/CuO, however, with the shortcoming of limited N2 selectivity [8,9]. The CeO2-based active NH3-SCR catalysts that possess good low-temperature activity, high N2 selectivity, and good SO2 resistance are the most sought-after solution to address these well-known yet elusive drawbacks. The precise distribution control of promoters can strengthen the interaction between promoters and ceria to enhance the catalytic performance of CeMOx [10–12]. Bimetallic metal-organic-frameworks (MOFs) are able to tailor the spatial distribution of cerium and promoter ions [13], that is otherwise, unable to attain when using conventional synthesis methods (e.g., wet impregnation, co-precipitation). Our previous study identifies that bimetallic oxides maximize the interaction between promoter and support and perform a much lower light-off temperature than catalysts prepared by conventional hydrothermal methods in the oxidation reaction of volatile organic compounds [14]. Nonetheless, the roles of such promoters in the mechanism of LT-SCR were far from fully understood, especially the redox/acidic of promoters and the spatial distribution of promoters on ceria which are crucial factors in LT-SCR. Herein, bimetallic MOF was used as the precursor, pre-organizing the distribution of promoters and ceria to produce CeMOx catalysts with a good interaction between promoters and ceria. Each model catalyst CeMOx was incorporated with only one promoter to investigate the redox/acidic nature of the promoter explicitly. We systematically characterized the CeTiOx and CeCuOx catalysts by combining ex situ and in situ measurements, e.g., XPS, NH3-TPD-MS, and in situ DRIFTS. Ex situ qualitative and quantitative analyses reveal the type and amount of reducibility and acidity of CeMOx, while in situ DRIFTS studies the adsorption and reaction of reactants in LT-SCR with and without H2O/SO2, thereby unveiling the properties-performance relationship. This study would enlighten the thoughts on designing ceria-based catalysts utilized in LT-SCR with high resistance to the H2O and SO2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials Cerium (III) chloride (CeCl3, 99%) and titanium (IV) isopropoxide (Ti{OCH(CH3)2}4, reagent grade), cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99%), copper (II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 99%), and terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 98%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. 5,5′-methylenediisophthalic acid (H4mdip, 95%) was purchased from Bidepharm. The formic acid (HCOOH, 98%), ethanol (99.9%), and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, AR) were used as solvents for the catalyst preparation that was purchased from Sinopharm. The chemicals were used as received without further purification. Distilled deionized (DDI) water was obtained from a Yamato WE200 water purifier system. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Bimetallic oxides were obtained by the thermal decomposition of bimetallic MOFs, which is prepared by a solvothermal method. The CeTiOx was synthesized using CeCl3, Ti{OCH(CH3)2}4 as metal precursors, and H4mdip as organic ligands for the bimetallic MOF precursor. The synthesis was carried out in an acid solution for the easy hydrolysis of Ti precursor. H4mdip (0.300 g, 0.87 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL HCOOH and ultrasonicated for 1.5 h, followed by dissolving CeCl3 (0.074 g, 0.30 mmol) and Ti{OCH(CH3)2}4 (0.36 mL, 0.60 mmol) into the solution. The obtained solutions were ultrasonicated for 15 min and transferred to the Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The solvothermal synthesis was carried out at 120 °C for 18 h. Purification of the obtained precipitate was performed by washing with ethanol several times. The CeTiOx was obtained by vacuum drying at 65 °C for 12 h, and calcination in air at 450 °C for 4 h. The CeCuOx and CeO2 were prepared by a similar templated method we reported previously [15]. Briefly, CeCuOx was derived from the calcination of CeCuBDC in the air at 350 °C for 4 h, and CeCuBDC was synthesized at 80 °C for 24 h using Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, and H2BDC. The reference catalyst CeO2 was templated from the calcination of CeBDC in air at 350 °C for 4 h, and the CeBDC was prepared at 100 °C for 24 h using Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and H2BDC. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of bimetallic MOF was carried out using TA55 thermogravimetric analyzer taken from ambient temperature to 700 °C in air at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The catalysts were examined under electron microscopes to determine the morphology and composition. The Hitachi SU8010 scanning electron microscope (SEM) was operated at an accelerating voltage of 3 kV and the catalyst was deposited on a clean silicon wafer and mounted on the aluminium holder by carbon tape and sputter-coated with platinum to minimize sample charging. The detailed morphological characteristics were studied by a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) using the Gatan Digital Micrograph program. This microscope is also equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) from Oxford Instrument for compositional analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were performed on a Nano-InXider system of Xenocs France using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). The micro-Raman spectra were obtained by a micro-Raman spectrometer (LabRAM Odyssey, Horiba) with a LEICA DMLM microscope using a 633 nm Ar laser light source with an acquisition time of 30 s for 4 scans. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was performed by a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Scientific). The spectra were collected from 400 to 4000 cm−1 at a resolution of 4 cm−1. N2 physisorption was conducted on an ASAP 2020 accelerated surface area and porosimetry analyzer (Micromeritics). All the samples were outgassed in vacuum at 200 ℃ before the N2 adsorption. The N2 physisorption isotherm was used to calculate the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area. The pore size distribution was obtained from the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model using the adsorption branch of the isotherm [16]. The catalyst surface was analyzed by a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250 Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) to understand the surface composition and oxygen species. The binding energy was calibrated to C 1 s at 285.0 eV. The redox properties of catalysts were investigated by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). It was performed on a AutoChem II 2920 automated chemisorption analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) detector. 0.1 g granular catalyst was packed into the reactor of the chemisorption analyzer, followed by pretreatment in He at 200 °C for 1 h. The temperature was programmed from 50 °C to 850 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in 10 vol% H2/Ar. The acidic properties of catalysts were studied by taking pyridine and ammonia as probe molecules, respectively. Pyridine-IR was conducted by a Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS20 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer in an ex situ manner. The pretreatment was carried out in vacuum at 250 °C for 60 min. The adsorption of pyridine vapor was performed at room temperature, and subsequently exposed in pure He to remove excess pyridine. Pyridine IR spectra were taken with a collection of 32 times and a resolution of 4 cm−1 at the temperatures of 50 °C, 150 °C, and 250 °C, respectively. The ammonia temperature-programmed desorption combing with mass spectroscopy (NH3-TPD-MS) was performed in a BELCAT II with TCD and a Bel Mass spectroscopy. 0.1 g catalyst was loaded in the fixed bed reactor, then heated up to 300 °C in 100 mL min−1 He and cooled to 50 °C. The NH3 adsorption was performed by feeding 10% NH3/He. The NH3-TPD measurement was performed in 100 mL min−1 He from 50 °C to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. 2.4 In situ DRIFTS investigation Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) experiments were performed on a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer, equipped with in situ diffuse reflectance cell (Harrick) and MCT detector cooled by liquid N2. The spectra were collected at a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 32 scans. The pretreatment was carried out by loading sample (0.04 g) in the cell and heating to 300 °C for 1 h in N2, followed by cooling to 50 °C. The background spectrum was collected at 50 °C. For the NH3 adsorption, 600 ppm NH3 was fed at 50°C for 1 h, and subsequently purged by N2 for 30 min In situ DRIFTS spectra of NH3 adsorption were collected from 50 °C to 350 °C. For the adsorption of NO + O2, 600 ppm NO and 3 vol% O2 was introduced in the gas chamber at 50 °C for 1 h. In situ DRIFTS spectra of NO + O2 co-adsorption were collected from 50 °C to 350 °C. To collect in situ DRIFT spectra of reaction, the sample was heated to 300 °C for 1 h in N2 before reaction, then cooled to reaction temperature of 225 °C, for collecting the background spectrum. For the reaction of NO + O2 with pre-adsorbed NH3, the sample was exposed to 600 ppm NH3 for 1 h, and purged by N2 for 30 min. Subsequently, in situ spectra were recorded in 100 mL min−1 flow of 600 ppm NO and 3 vol% O2. For the reaction of NH3 with pre-adsorbed NO + O2, the catalyst was exposed to 600 ppm NO and 3 vol% O2 for 1 h. In situ DRIFT spectra were obtained in 600 ppm NH3 at a flow rate of 100 mL min−1. The co-adsorption of SO2 + O2 was carried out at a reaction temperature of 225 °C after pretreatment. The catalyst was exposed to a flow of 400 ppm SO2 and 3 vol% O2, and the spectra were recorded continuously for 30 min. For adsorption of NH3 with SO2 pretreatment, the sample was pretreated in 400 ppm SO2 and purged in N2 for 30 min. Then, 100 mL min−1 600 ppm NH3 was purged in the gas chamber and the spectra were recorded at 30 min. For the adsorption of NO + O2 with SO2 pretreatment, the sample was pretreated with 400 ppm SO2 and purged with N2 for 30 min. Then 600 ppm NO and 3 vol% O2 were purged in the cell at a flow rate of 100 mL min−1 and the spectra were recorded at 30 min The co-adsorption of NH3 + H2O was conducted at 225 °C after pretreatment, and the background spectrum was collected. The spectra were collected sample when exposed to 600 ppm NH3 and 5 vol% H2O for 1 h. For the co-adsorption of NO + O2 + H2O, the spectra were collected at 600 ppm NO, 3 vol% O2 and 5 vol% H2O for 1 h. For the co-adsorption of NH3 + NO + O2 + H2O, the spectra were collected when the sample was exposed to 600 ppm NH3, 600 ppm NO, 3 vol% O2, and 5 vol% H2O for 1 h. 2.5 Catalytic performance test The catalytic remediation of flue gas was investigated in a fixed bed reactor simulating the real exhaust conditions. The catalyst was pelleted, crushed and sieved to obtain the granule catalysts of 40–60 mesh. 0.2 g catalyst was packed into a stainless-steel tubular reactor with a catalyst bed diameter of 6 mm. The reactor was embedded in a tubular heater, where the temperature was monitored by a thermocouple inserted into the reactor above the catalyst bed. The flue gases were fed into the reactor at a flow rate of 500 mL min−1 to give a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 150,000 h−1. Typically, the simulated flue gas consisted of 600 ppm NH3, 600 ppm NO, 3 vol% O2, and N2 for balance. Additionally, 100 ppm SO2 and 5 vol% H2O were introduced to the system to test the resistance to SO2 and H2O. The gaseous components were modulated by mass flow controllers (MFC) and mixed in a gas chamber to obtain the simulated flue gases. The catalytic performance in the flue gas was analyzed by a FTIR gas analyzer (Nicolet iS50 FTIR equipped with an online gas cell operated at 110 °C). The NOx conversion and N2 selectivity were determined as follows: (1) NO x Conversion % = NO x in − NO x out NO x in × 100 % (2) N 2 Selectivity ( % ) = ( 1 − 2 × N 2 O out NO x in + NH 3 in − NO x out − NH 3 out ) × 100 % where [NOx] represents the total concentration of NO and NO2. [NOx]in and [NH3]in are the steady-state concentrations of NOx and NH3 at the reactor inlet for a given reaction temperature, and [NOx]out, [NH3]out and [N2O]out are the concentration of NOx, NH3, and N2O at the reactor outlet, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Transformation from bimetallic MOFs to CeMOx catalysts Fig. 1 displays the synthesis scheme and microstructure of CeTiOx and CeCuOx characterized by SEM, TEM and EDS element mapping. The Ce-Ti clusters (Fig. 1a) were first complexed within the organic ligand network to form a stable bimetallic MOF, i.e., CeTi-MOF, followed by thermal decomposition at 436 °C to remove the organic ligands and transform into CeTiOx (Fig. S1-S2). The obtained bimetallic oxides catalysts retained the morphology of their MOF precursors but with a rougher surface. CeTiOx presented an erythrocyte shape with a diameter of 0.10 ± 0.01 µm, as shown in the TEM micrographs (Fig. 1b). The corresponding EDS elemental mapping images in Fig. 1b demonstrate a coincidence of Ce, Ti, and O, indicating a homogenous distribution in CeTiOx. This is the crucial feature for bimetallic MOFs templated catalyst to form homogenously distributed promoter and support, where the atom of designated promoters and supports are prearranged within the MOF template. Also, the HRTEM observation in Fig. 1c points towards the formation of a mesoporous structure consisting of interpenetrating CeO2- and TiO2-rich nanodomains, as indicated by the characteristic d-spacings of CeO2 (111) and TiO2 (101). Analogous to CeTiOx, CeCuOx was also synthesized with the similar templated method (Fig. 1d). 2D rhombic CeCuOx (Fig. 1e) presented more defects at the grain boundaries (Fig. 1f) than that of CeTiOx (Fig. 1c). Both CeTiOx and CeCuOx were mesoporous materials with type H3 hysteresis (Fig. S3). Comparable surface area of 93.6 m2 g−1 for CeTiOx and 90.1 m2 g−1 for CeCuOx were obtained (Table S1). The HRTEM micrograph and porosity analysis showed that both catalysts possessed an extremely uniform composition and comparable porous structure, which are desired for efficient catalytic performance. It would allow a straightforward investigation of the redox/acidic properties of promoter and their influence in LT-SCR. 3.2 Crystalline phase and structural features of CeMOx catalysts The formation of CeO2 and anatase TiO2 on CeTiOx was confirmed by XRD pattern ( Fig. 2a). CeTiOx displayed a diffraction pattern indexed to CeO2 (JCPDS 34–0394) and anatase TiO2 (JCPDS 21–1272). The crystal sizes of CeO2 and TiO2 are calculated from XRD pattern of CeTiOx using Debye-Scherrer equation. CeO2 and TiO2 exhibit crystal sizes of 4.6 nm and 6.8 nm, respectively, which are much smaller than CeO2 (10.2 nm) and CuO (12.8 nm) of CeCuOx (Table S1). Micro-Raman spectroscopy which is more sensitive was employed to detect the small changes in chemical bonding of catalysts. The CeO2 derived from Ce-MOF [15] was cited as a reference catalyst to investigate the promoter influence. A redshift of 8 cm−1 was detected for F2g mode of CeTiOx (456 cm−1) in comparison to pure CeO2 (464 cm−1) (Fig. 2b and Table S2). This shift indicates the strong interfacial interaction between the nanoscale-mixed CeO2 and TiO2 in CeTiOx. More pronounced shifts were found on CeCuOx with a 0.3° shift to higher diffraction angles in XRD patterns (Fig. 2a) and a redshift of 16 cm−1 (Fig. 2b) in Raman spectrum. In addition to nanoscale-mixing, these shifts reveal a smaller lattice parameter in CeCuOx than pure CeO2, which is related to the aliovalent substitution of copper into ceria lattice during the transformation from MOF precursor to bimetallic oxides. It is anticipated to enhance the redox properties of catalyst [17,18]. 3.3 Catalytic performance in NH3-SCR of CeMOx catalysts Fig. 3 compares the catalytic performance of CeTiOx, CeCuOx and CeO2 in LT-SCR at a high GHSV of 150,000 h−1. The CeTiOx presented a LT-SCR activity of 50% conversion (T50) and 90% conversion (T90) at 158 ℃ and 197 ℃, respectively, with over 80% from 180 ℃ to 300 ℃. Additionally, the N2 selectivity maintained nearly 100% at the temperature range (Fig. 3a and Fig. S4). The good performance of CeTiOx might be related to the strong interaction between the characteristic titania and ceria, as inferred from XRD pattern and Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 2). In contrast, copper species of CeCuOx were found to promote the LT-SCR when the temperature was lower than 200 ℃. It displayed a T50 at 156 ℃, which is slightly lower than CeTiOx (158 ℃). However, an obvious drop in NOx conversion was observed as the reaction temperatures were over 200 ℃, producing N2O and NO2 (Fig. S4). The CeO2 catalyst without promoters exhibited the lowest activity in LT-SCR requiring a T50 of 225 ℃, and was unable to achieve conversion higher than 70% (Fig. 3a). Its N2 selectivity dropped dramatically with rising temperatures, producing primarily NO2 as byproducts (Fig. S4). Fig. 3a determines that CeTiOx performed better in LT-SCR than CeCuOx and CeO2, which is promising as compared to the catalysts prepared by conventional methods (or using other conditions, Fig. S5, S6) and the catalysts reported in the literature (Table S3). Sulfur compounds and humidity are typically present in the flue gas and deactivate the SCR catalysts. To investigate the resistance towards sulfur compounds and humidity, the best performed CeTiOx catalyst was evaluated in an atmosphere of 100 ppm SO2 and 5 vol% H2O for the LT-SCR. As shown in Fig. 3b, the CeTiOx catalysts showed a negligible loss of NOx conversion (ca. 1.7%) in the presence of 100 ppm SO2, and recovered to initial conversion (ca. 92.0%) after the SO2 flow was turned off. The decrease of activity in 5 vol% water vapor was 1.2%, and approximately 2.3% decline in activity was recorded in feed that contained both 100 ppm SO2 and 5 vol% H2O; CeTiOx was able to recover from this slight deactivation. The 30 h on-stream NH3-SCR test in Fig. 3b suggests CeTiOx had superior stability. Furthermore, the bimetallic MOF templated CeTiOx with abundant crystalline boundary (Fig. 1), could potentially inhibit the deposition of bulk sulfate, therefore alleviating the deactivation of catalyst. The nature of active sites also affects the adsorption of SO2 and OH- and the deposition of sulfate species on CeTiOx. To map out the property-activity relationship, multiple techniques (i.e., XPS, NH3-TPD-MS, pyridine-IR, in situ DRIFTS) were applied to thoroughly investigate the catalytic characteristics. 3.4 Redox properties of CeMOx catalysts The chemical statues and surface oxygen species of CeCuOx and CeTiOx were determined by XPS analysis. CeTiOx and CeCuOx were characterized with O 1 s, Ce 3d, Ti 2p and Cu 2p, respectively ( Fig. 4a). The Ce4+ was identified by u′′′ (917.0 eV), u′′ (907.9 eV), u (901.2 eV), and v′′′ (898.6 eV), v′′ (889.3 eV), v (882.5 eV), Ce3+ was denoted as u′ (902.2 eV), u0 (900.3 eV), v′ (884.3 eV) and v0 (880.2 eV) [19]. Fig. 4b illustrates the coexistence of the Ce4+ and Ce3+ species on both CeTiOx and CeCuOx. The Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) of CeTiOx (i.e., 38.9%) was significantly higher than that of CeCuOx (i.e., 25.9%) and CeO2 (i.e., 23.1%), as calculated from the peak area in Table 1. The Ti 2p band of CeTiOx (Fig. 4c) primarily exhibited Ti4+ (i.e., 95.2%) at 464.6 eV and 458.8 eV. The large amount of Ce3+ and Ti4+ on the surface of CeTiOx confirms the strong interaction at the crystal boundary and formation of Ti4+-O-Ce3+ that can accelerate the electron transfer in NH3-SCR [6,20]. The Cu 2p spectrum of CeCuOx (Fig. 4d) presented Cu+ at 932.4 eV, and Cu2+ at 933.6 eV, with the presence of shake-up satellites that verifies the Cu2+ existence [21]. Approximately 15% of copper on the CeCuOx was in the reduced status of Cu+. The O 1 s spectra of both catalysts (Fig. 4e) displayed a band at 529.6 eV attributed to the lattice oxygen (Oα) and a band at 531.5 eV assigned to the adsorbed oxygen species adjacent to oxygen vacancies (Oβ) [18]. The incorporation of aliovalent metal ions (Cu as +2) in ceria (Ce as +4) lattice at nano-crystalline boundary triggered the formation of oxygen vacancies, as suggested by the Oβ proportion of 33.7%. Furthermore, the H2-TPR studies were also performed to investigate the redox properties (Fig. S7). It shows that the incorporation of both Ti- and Cu- promoters on CeO2 distinctly decreased the reduction temperatures, especially for CeCuOx, which benefited the redox process at low temperature (Fig. 3a). 3.5 Acidic properties of CeMOx catalysts The acidity of catalysts is crucial for the NH3-SCR, especially for the NH3 adsorption. The pyridine-IR ( Fig. 5) and NH3-TPD-MS ( Fig. 6) of CeTiOx, CeCuOx, and CeO2 catalysts were carried out to identify the type and strength of acid sites, respectively. Pyridine IR spectra of all three catalysts (Fig. 5) displayed vibration of pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites (i.e., LPy species at 1595, 1575, 1485, 1442 cm−1, summarized in Table S4) [22]. The pyridine adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites (i.e., BPy species at 1541 cm−1) was observed on the CeTiOx (Fig. 5a), and much weaker on the CeCuOx (Fig. 5b) and CeO2 (Fig. 5c). Pyridine IR results indicate CeTiOx consists of both Lewis (L-) and Brønsted (B-) acid sites, while CeCuOx and CeO2 primarily have L- acid sites with limited B-acid sites. Moreover, the LPy species on CeCuOx (Fig. 5b) gradually converted to oxidized pyridine as temperature increased, presenting carboxylate species (1605, 1550 cm−1) with consumption of the reactive basic O2 - species (1005 cm−1) [22,23]. The formation of carboxylates and the consumption of O2 - suggested that the decline in reactivity of CeCuOx might be due to the peroxidation of adsorbed NH3 or NOx (Fig. 3a) [24]. The adsorbed pyridine on CeTiOx was hardly oxidized by O2 -, which illustrated its good thermal stability and wide working temperature window of NH3-SCR (Fig. 3). The NH3-TPD-MS curves (Fig. 6 and Fig. S8) demonstrated that disparate compositions of CeTiOx and CeCuOx resulted in a huge difference in the acidity strength. The NH3-TPD curves (Fig. 6) were fitted according to the MS results (Fig. S8). The first desorption centered at 133 °C (Peak I) is assigned to the physical NH3 adsorptions of all the catalysts [25]. The second desorption (Peak II) is attributed to the weak acid sites [26,27]. A shoulder peak of CeTiOx at 401 °C (Peak III) is ascribed to the strong acid sites [28]. The participation of strong acid sites in NH3-SCR (Fig. 3) was indicated by the detection of N2 in the outgas of NH3-TPD at 416 °C (Fig. S8) [26,27]. The Peak IV of CeCuOx and CeO2 that required a higher desorption temperature (over 500 °C), which favored the NH3 dehydrogenation to NH, reacted with NOx to produce N2O (Fig. S4) [29]. This might explain the low selectivity of CeO2 and CeCuOx at high temperatures of NH3-SCR (Fig. 3a). Total NH3 desorption amount of CeTiOx (i.e., peak area of 1775.8) was much higher than CeCuOx (864.2) and CeO2 (727.4), providing abundant sites for NH3 adsorption in LT-SCR ( Table 2). CeTiOx exhibited the highest amount of weak acid sites of 852.2, followed by CeCuOx (385.3) and CeO2 (305.9). Both CeTiOx and CeCuOx required a lower Peak II desorption temperature of 220 °C than CeO2 (278 °C), explaining their better LT activity. 3.6 In situ DRIFTS studies of the CeMOx In situ DRIFTS measurements of reactant adsorption (cf. Figs. 7 and 8), and the reaction between NH3 and NOx (cf. Figs. 9 and 10) were employed to figure out the promoter’s effect on the mechanistic process. The adsorptions of NH3, NOx in the presence of SO2 and H2O were also carried out on the best-performed CeTiOx to identify the roles of surface sites play in a stable LT-SCR reaction (cf. Fig. 11). 3.6.1 NH3 adsorption The negative peaks (3660, 1630 cm−1) are ascribed to the consumption of the surface H2O and −OH species [30,31]. The CeTiOx (Fig. 7a) presented NH3 adsorbed on both L-acid sites (3373, 3254, 3161, 1179 cm−1) and B-acid sites (1455 cm−1) [11,32]. Partial of adsorbed NH3 on CeTiOx was gradually dehydrogenated and oxidized as the temperature increased to form NH2 (1346 cm−1) [33,34] and monodentate nitrate (1558 cm−1) [11,32] that can be facilely reacted in LT-SCR (Fig. 7a). For CeCuOx, NH3 was mainly adsorbed on L-acid sites (1220 cm−1) [33,35], which quickly converted to bridge nitrate (1230 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1522 cm−1) and disappeared at a low temperature of 150 °C (Fig. 7b). The fast peroxidation of adsorbed NH3 was consistent with the strong redox properties of CeCuOx (Fig. S7), resulting in poor N2 selectivity in NH3-SCR (Fig. 3). CeO2 presented the coordinated NH3 on L-acid sites (1545, 1252, 1100 cm−1) that accumulated on the surface before being converted to nitrate species (1519, 1371, 1226 cm−1) at high temperatures (Fig. 7c) [33,35]. The percentages of L- and B-acid (Fig. 7d) were calculated based on the ratio of IR peak area (Fig. 7a-c), and the amounts of the L- and B-acid (Fig. 7e) were estimated from the total acidity detected by NH3-TPD (Fig. 6, Table 2). The Ti introduction of CeTiOx increased the percentage of B-acid sites from 23% to 33% (cf. Fig. 7d), and the number of B-acid sites of CeTiOx was two times higher than those of CeCuOx and CeO2. It may due to the formation of Ti-OH sites on the CeTiOx [36]. The highest acidity of CeTiOx provided abundant sites for NH3 adsorption. The percentage and amount of L- and B-acid for CeCuOx are similar to those of CeO2 with primarily L-acid sites (ca. 80%), implying Cu promoter did not modify the CeCuOx acidity. In situ DRIFTS study of NH3 adsorption (Fig. 7) shows that NH3 was adsorbed on CeTiOx primarily on L-acid and B-acid, while it was adsorbed as nitrate species on CeCuOx and CeO2. To further testify, NH3-TPO was performed in a flow with NH3 and O2 in the absence of NOx (Fig. S9). It determines that ammonia was activated at a lower temperature on CeCuOx (150 °C) than on CeTiOx (250 °C). This implies that the higher NOx conversion of CeCuOx than CeTiOx at low temperature is most likely via a process where NH3 was oxidized to NOx that later reacted with NH3 to produce N2 and H2O. CeO2 follows a similar process with CeCuOx. In contrast, the NH3 oxidation was not obvious on CeTiOx at a lower temperature (<300 ℃). 3.6.2 NO + O2 adsorption To explore the adsorbed NOx species, in situ DRIFTS spectra of catalysts were recorded (Fig. 8). After co-adsorption of NO and O2 at 50 °C, the monodentate nitrate (1606, 1558, 1353 cm−1), and chelating nitrite (1296, 1250 cm−1) were detected on the spectrum of CeTiOx (Fig. 8a) [11,32]. The adsorbed NOx on CeTiOx was in the form of monodentate nitrate at temperature up to 275 °C. Monodentate nitrate can be easily reacted in NH3-SCR, and much less nitrate species were occupied on CeTiOx, which is in good accordance with its high reactivity (Fig. 3). Monodentate nitrate (1616, 1194 cm−1) were also found on CeCuOx (Fig. 8b) and CeO2 (Fig. 8c) at low temperatures, but later replaced by the bidentate nitrate (1522 cm−1) and bridge nitrate (1230 cm−1) as temperatures were higher than 175 °C [11,32]. Bidentate nitrates and bridge nitrate occupied the catalyst surface of CeCuOx (Fig. 8b) and CeO2 (Fig. 8c) that subsequently inhibited the NH3-SCR. 3.6.3 Reaction between NO + O2 and preadsorbed NH3 species The reactivity between pre-adsorbed NH3 and NOx at 225 °C was studied by in situ DRIFTS (Fig. 9). Adsorbed NH3 on the L-acid site of CeTiOx (i.e., 3371, 3254, 3161, 1179 cm−1) [31,32] consumed quickly within 1 min after feeding NOx, followed by accumulation of monodentate nitrate (1606, 1558, 1353 cm−1) on the surface (Fig. 9a) [11,32]. A longer time of 2 min was required by CeCuOx for the pre-adsorbed NH3 to react with NOx (Fig. 9b) before the accumulation of multiple types of nitrate species (i.e., monodentate-1606, 1558 cm−1, bidentate-1528 cm−1, and bridge-1240, 1208, 1215 cm−1) [11,32]. The NH3 pre-adsorbed on CeO2 was hardly converted and occupied the catalyst surface (Fig. 9c), explaining its low reactivity [11,32]. Accordingly, Fig. 9 clarifies that high activity of CeTiOx was from its fast reaction between NO and adsorbed-NH3. Moreover, NO adsorption on CeTiOx as monodentate nitrate instead of bidentate/bridge nitrates, might also accelerate the NOx conversion to N2 and H2O (Fig. 3a). 3.6.4 Reaction between NH3 and preadsorbed NO + O2 species The reactivity of pre-adsorbed NO + O2 with NH3 was also investigated by in situ DRIFTS (Fig. 10). After introducing NH3, the adsorbed NOx (monodentate nitrate at 1606, 1558 cm−1) on CeTiOx gradually decreased along with the reaction time and vanished in 10 min (Fig. 10a) [11,32]. Afterwards, the NH3 adsorbed on L-acid sites (3371, 3254, 3161, 1179 cm−1) accumulated on CeTiOx [31,32]. It demonstrated that adsorbed NOx in the form of monodentate nitrate is the active intermediate in LT-SCR. Insignificant change of bidentate nitrate (1528 cm−1) during the process hints that it is less active than monodentate nitrate when participating in LT-SCR [11,32]. The consumption of monodentate nitrate was also observed on CeCuOx (Fig. 10b), but required a longer time of 20 min compared to that of CeTiOx (10 min). The high redox ability of CeCuOx resulted in further oxidation of adsorbed NH3 to bidentate nitrate (1522 cm−1) and bridge nitrate (1230 cm−1) that needed high activation energy to be reacted. There was no change in CeO2 when switching to NH3 (Fig. 10c), suggesting it is difficult to convert adsorbed NOx on CeO2 by feeding NH3. 3.6.5 The effect of SO2 and H2O Fig. 11a shows in situ IR spectra of CeTiOx when exposed to 400 ppm SO2 in the presence of 3 vol% O2. After feeding SO2 and O2, various oxidized SO2 species were observed on CeTiOx that ascribed to the thiosulphate (1623 cm−1) [37], catalytically active sulfate species (1385 cm−1) [38], and tridentate sulfate groups (1318 cm−1) [39]. Fig. 11b displays the spectra before and after feeding NH3 to the SO2 pre-adsorbed CeTiOx. Interestingly, besides the NH3 adsorbed on L-acid sites (i.e., 3354, 3259, 3156, 1602, 1187 cm−1) and molecularly adsorbed SO2 (1275 cm−1), the apparent increased intensity of NH3 on B-acid sites (1434 cm−1) indicated that the presence of SO2 improved the NH3 adsorption [31,32]. Furthermore, no ammonia sulfate was produced during the NH3 adsorption on CeTiOx, as its abundant crystalline boundary derived from bimetallic MOF could potentially prevent the bulk sulfate deposition (Fig. 1) [40]. As observed in Fig. 11c, upon the NOx adsorption on the SO2-pretreated CeTiOx, it mainly exhibited the vibrations of adsorbed SO2 species (1621, 1385 cm−1) with shoulder peaks of monodentate nitrate (1554, 1367 cm−1). These results imply that SO2 mainly competed with NOx instead of NH3 for adsorption in LT-SCR. Since NOx adsorption is less dominant compared to NH3 adsorption, therefore illustrating the limited effects of SO2 on CeTiOx in LT-SCR (Fig. 3b) [41]. Fig. 11d-f presents that the adsorption of NH3 and NO was not altered by H2O dramatically, clarifying the high stability of CeTiOx in the presence of 5 vol% water vapor (Fig. 3b). Overall, it is well-known that the redox properties and acidity are two crucial factors that demonstrate the performance of NH3-SCR catalysts. In this work, the highly homogeneous bimetallic MOF-derived CeMOx (Fig. 1) enabled the precise investigation of the promoter effects and the properties-activity relationship. The large amount of Ce3+ and Ti4+ of CeTiOx (Fig. 4 and Table 1) indicated its redox property was improved by strong interaction between TiO2 and CeO2 via Ti3+ + Ce4+→ Ti4+ + Ce3+ that inherited from the bimetallic MOF precursor [6,20]. Ti promoters also enhanced the acidity of CeTiOx significantly, most likely by introducing Ti4+=O and Ti4+-OH as acid sites (Figs. 5 and 6). The developed CeTiOx shows an over 80% NOx conversion from 180 ℃ to 300 ℃ with 100% N2 selectivity (Fig. 3). Cu introduction into CeCuOx triggered the aliovalent substitution of Cu2+ into CeO2 at the nano-crystalline boundary, producing abundant oxygen vacancies (Fig. 1−2 and Table 1). It accelerated the O2 activation, enhancing the NH3-SCR at low-temperatures (Fig. 3) [42]. However, the extremely high redox properties of CeCuOx with rapid O2 activation (Fig. 4) induced the NH3 peroxidation and led to a low N2 selectivity that produced NO2 and N2O (Fig. 3 and Fig. S4). In situ DRIFT determines the reaction between NO and pre-adsorbed NH3 (cf. 1 min, Fig. 9a) was faster than the reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO (cf. 10 min, Fig. 10a), suggesting NH3 adsorption was a dominant step in LT-SCR. Although SO2 competed with NO for adsorption (Fig. 11c), the CeTiOx catalyst was not deactivated, confirming that the NO adsorption was less crucial for NH3-SCR compared to NH3 adsorption. These observations demonstrate the NH3-SCR catalyzed by CeTiOx was primarily via a Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism (the reaction between the adsorbed NH3 and the gaseous NOx). Moreover, nitrate species produced by NOx adsorption was observed at low temperature and consumed as temperature increased (Fig. 8). It might also participate the NH3-SCR through Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism especially at low temperature range, where nitrates react with adsorbed NH3 to produce NH4NO2/NH4NO3 that decomposes to N2 and H2O [43]. The reaction activity of the monodentate nitrate of CeCuOx can be seen in Fig. 10. The formation of monodentate nitrate on CeCuOx at low temperature after NO+O2 adsorption can be seen from the IR spectrum indicating the adsorbed NOx was participated in the NH3-SCR at the low temperature via L-H mechanism. The fast reaction between adsorbed NH3 and gaseous NOx (Fig. 9), implies the higher acidity consisting of both L- and B-acid sites of CeTiOx than CeCuOx and CeO2, facilitated NH3 adsorption and NH3-SCR principally by E-R mechanism. 4 Conclusions This work synthesized CeMOx (M=Ti, Cu) catalysts with a homogeneous distribution of promoters and support via a rarely reported method using bimetallic MOFs precursors to discuss the crucial factor such as redox/acidic features for low-temperature NH3-SCR (LT-SCR). Ti existed in oxidized status Ti4+ that strongly interacted with the CeO2. The high acidity consisting of both L- and B-acid sites with good redox properties of CeTiOx facilitated the NH3 adsorption and accelerated the reaction between NOx and adsorbed NH3. Furthermore, the existence of SO2 improved the B-acid sites, and water vapor had a scarce influence on the adsorption of NH3 or NOx (Fig. 11). As a result, CeTiOx yielded over 80% NOx conversion with 100% N2 selectivity in the NH3-SCR and no deactivation in the 30 h stability test of 100 ppm SO2 and 5 vol% H2O. In contrast, the aliovalent substitution of Cu into CeO2 lattice triggered the generation of oxygen vacancies at the nano-crystalline boundary to promote its redox properties (cf. Fig. 4 and Fig. S7). It showed a low reaction temperature of 125 °C in LT-SCR but deactivated sharply at temperature higher than 200 °C (Fig. 3b). In situ DRIFTS of NH3-adsorption indicates that the deactivation was due to the peroxidation of NH3, where the high surface oxygen species oxidized the adsorbed NH3 on L-acid sites (Fig. 7b). The high redox properties undermined the activity by deep oxidation of adsorbed NOx to bidentate/bridge nitrate that hardly converted in NH3-SCR (Figs. 8–10). It reveals that the redox properties of catalysts improve the activity of LT-SCR. Still, too high reducibility with insufficient Brønsted acid sites leads to the peroxidation of reactants, which undermines the N2 selectivity. Overall, our work enlightens the thoughts on the design of low-temperature deNOx catalyst by providing a method to produce highly uniform model catalysts to investigate the properties-performance relationship. coredata.dc:description: Low-temperature selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (LT-SCR) is a promising approach for NOx remediation. This work utilized bimetallic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) to prepare CeMOx (M=Ti, Cu) catalysts allowing the homogeneous distribution of promoters to investigate LT-SCR explicitly. The strong interfacial interaction between nanoscale-mixed components was characterized on CeTiOx by HRTEM, micro-Raman, and XPS, resulting in high acidity and good redox properties with abundant Ce3+ and Ti4+. It obtained over 80% conversion from 180 °C to 300 °C with 100% N2 selectivity, and maintained stable performance in SO2/H2O at a high GHSV of 150,000 h−1. In situ DRIFTS reveals that NH3 adsorption was promoted on CeTiOx, which accelerated reaction between NOx and adsorbed NH3 via Eley-Rideal mechanism. Meanwhile, the aliovalent substitution of ceria by Cu2+ was observed on CeCuOx, forming oxygen vacancies. Its high redox properties enhanced NOx conversion by Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism, but triggered NH3 peroxidation, leading to poor N2 selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation on the redox/acidic features of bimetallic MOF-derived CeMOx catalysts for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NOx
